So they're rewarding publishers who have such a terrible design that users had to restyle their content?

so you could have just saved it for later, not because it was ugly

yeah, it's like the cost model is inverted
This whole situation confuses me
instead of paying for the mobile app you pay for the service
I guess a way to get people to pay twice for the same product?
yeah, i'm still thinking of them as separate
Marco's post seems to cast Readability as only the publisher payout part, which i guess makes more sense
that's great that they're working with instapaper. definitely paying for that
despite it making no real sense to pay for it. on paper.
but if you sign up for that, you get Instapaper's functionality for free
yeah, it's confusing
well virtual paper
http://kindlebility.darkhax.com/ Is useful for the kindle owners.
@dreid hey that's cool

Probably a couple of things that make the Readability plan clearer: First, yeah, the Ry team is working with Marco and the mobile apps are just rebranded Instapaper. Second, Readability has lots of regular, non-geek users who have the bookmarklet and use it on sites for legibility reasons, etc. Those folks are a broader audience than the hardcore Instapaper users. And the idea behind the payment model is to make something publishers like and work with, instead of getting in to some sort of blocking war with them. Key thing is it is about making a really good reading experience that's not tied to one publisher, but works across all of them.
@dreid Thanks for the shoutout! Glad you like it.
